intro: Senecio gawlerensis, commonly known as the Gawler iceplant, is an endemic species native to the arid regions of South Australia. It is a low-growing, mat-forming plant with succulent, fleshy leaves that store water, enabling it to survive in dry conditions. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming in spring. Its leaves are often covered in a fine layer of white, waxy powder, which reflects sunlight and reduces water loss. This species is adapted to sandy or rocky soils and is considered a rare and vulnerable plant due to habitat loss and environmental changes.
